text: Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review1 Emmanuel Petit* Since Elster’s seminal review [1998], an abundant literature has revealed the growing interest of economists in the question of emotions. The introduction of emotion into economic analysis has been carried out essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion. Developing a richer and more complete economy of emotions makes it necessary to also draw on other approaches to emotion, notably from sociology, anthropology, history and philosophy. The aim of this article is to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions. The first step is to identify the major stages in the construction of this theory and to extract the essential properties of emotions. The aim is then to illustrate how this knowledge has been mobilized in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline. Introduction Since Elster's seminal review [1998], an abundant literature has revealed the growing interest of economists in the question of emotions (Loewenstein [2000], Camerer et al.
[2005], Rick et Loewenstein [2008], Lerner et al.
[2015], Petit [2009, 2015], Dunning et al.
[2017], Gomes [2017], Winter [2017], Wälde et Moors [2017], Tkach [2019], Rolls [2019]).

As in many academic disciplines, economists have accompanied what historians have called "the emotional turn" (Plam-per [2010]), an extraordinary craze born in the mid-1990s for the study of emotions. In economics, emotions are today mainly mobilized and studied in an experimental framework and then introduced into behavioral models in order to improve existing models of human behavior. The "economics of emotions" (Petit [2015]) has made it possible to "revisit" the model of perfect rationality (Elster [1996], Kahneman [2012], Rolls [2019]), has introduced a plurality of social and/or moral motivations (Jourdheuil and Petit [2015]) and has led to new modalities of intervention by public authorities such as emotional paternalism (Schultz et al. [2007]). The introduction of emotion into economic analysis was carried out essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion. As suggested by Elster [1998], this conception made it possible (i) to disturb emotion in categories that could be easily mobilized by economists, (ii) to give it a functional (multi-component) definition particularly adapted to the methodological individualism practiced in experimental and behavioral economics and above all (iii) to provide precise and effective instruments for measuring and inducing emotions. The theory of emotions that was gradually established during the 20th century, however, covers a much broader field of analysis than that taken into account by psychology and neuroscience. Other disciplines – such as sociology, philosophy, anthropology, history or literature – have also constructed an elaborate and fruitful theory of emotions. Recent work on the theory of emotions also shows that there is now a convergence between approaches that were once opposed and considered incompatible (biology vs. anthropology, psychology vs. sociology). Developing a richer and more complete “economy of emotions” makes it necessary to know and draw on the different approaches to emotion, without limiting ourselves to the sole conception of psychology and/or neurology. The aim of this review is therefore to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions. First, it is a question of identifying the main stages in the construction of this theory and extracting the essential properties of emotions (2). The aim then is to illustrate – as extensively as possible but without claiming to be exhaustive – how this knowledge has been used in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline (3). We will conclude this review of the literature on the theory and economics of emotions by discussing and identifying the most fruitful and promising areas of research for economists (4).

triplets.head: Elster
triplets.tail: psychological and neurological conception of emotion

text: We will finally conclude briefly (5). 2.

The science of emotions: expression, behavior, and social construction It is possible to juxtapose two major conceptions in contemporary scientific approaches to emotion23. First, there are the authors who consider that emotions correspond to an objective empirical reality that can be defined, analyzed, evaluated, and broken down. Schematically, the proponents of this first trend are more located in the life sciences, in the medical sciences, or in experimental sciences such as psychology or neuroscience. Within this first trend, there are, on the one hand, those who give primacy to the bodily, physiological, biological dimension of emotion (2.1) and, on the other hand, those who, by relativizing the scope of the body, reveal the importance of cognition and psychological processes (2.2). Other authors, on the contrary, argue that emotions should be considered rather as objects on which we can formulate a discourse without claiming an operational measurement.
These authors share the idea that the human mind bases its capacity for knowledge on relationships 2.

This is naturally a schematic juxtaposition that allows the question of emotion to be approached with clarity and relative simplicity, especially for the uninitiated. However, the reader must keep in mind that the porosity, contiguity and overlap between the work of researchers belonging to different disciplines (neurology, sociology, social psychology, anthropology, philosophy, etc.) is much greater than what the following presentation of the theory of emotions suggests. Some works in particular are explicitly on the border between these disciplines (for example, overlapping neuroscience and history as an illustration (see in this regard the evocatively titled work by Smail [2007]).  3.
In the following, we refer to the references and original editions of the texts or works of the authors cited.

For extensive and recent disciplinary academic reviews on the theory of emotions, the reader may consult in particular Lewis et al. [2010] and Tcherkassof [2008] in psychology, Panksepp [2004] in neuroscience, Stets and Turner [2014] in sociology, Goldie [2009] in philosophy, Beatty [2019] in anthropology, Biess and Gross [2014] in philosophy of science, Hoggett and Thompson [2012] and Nussbaum [2013] in political science, Plantin [2011] in communication sciences.

text: The history of emotions has been remarkably documented by Corbin et al.
For a historical introduction, see also Plamper [2015] as well as the articles by Boquet and Nagy [2011, 2016].
For a historical reading of the word “emotion”, refer to Dixon [2012]. The reader will also find a summary of the place of emotion in art in Bernardet al.
[2016], in architecture, in Thibault [2010], and around the heritage question, in Fabre [2013].

On the place of emotions in the construction of scientific knowledge, refer to the very fine work of Waquet [2019]. Finally, for synthetic and enlightened dictionaries of the words of emotion and “social passions”, see respectively Smith [2019] and Origgi [2019]. Emmanuel Petit— ... The supporters of this second conception are located in the human and social sciences (history, sociology, anthropology, etc.) and highlight the scope of social norms and cultures in which emotion is expressed: this is part of what is called the "social construction" of emotions (2.3). 2.1.
The physiological and biological dimension of emotion The first scientific approach to the theory of emotions emphasizes the physiological, biological and universal dimension of emotion.

We can summarize it by saying that emotion is located in the body and that consequently emotions can be produced, expressed and recognized by any human, regardless of their culture. An emotion like fear, for example, would have this universal, innate, natural dimension, which is manifested by certain facial expressions (tensing) or body expressions (trembling, cold sweat, palpitations, etc.). For a very long time, many thinkers have sought to locate emotion in the body.

This is the case of several Greek authors (Hippocrates, Galen), Romans, ecclesiastical theologians (Augustine, Thomas Aquinas), but also of Descartes [1649], Condillac [1754], Smith [1759] or Diderot and d'Alembert [1765].

However, it is thanks to Darwin's theory of evolution [1872] that bodily theories of emotion receive a major boost. In Darwin's naturalistic approach [1872], emotions are conceived as current vestiges of the distant origins of the human species.

triplets.head: current vestiges
triplets.tail: distant origins of the human species

text: They serve the organism by allowing it to react with appropriate behaviors to dangers from the environment. For example, in the case of surprise, opening the eyes and fixing the gaze would facilitate the detection and identification of unexpected events.

Emotions also have a primary function of social communication or signaling when, through the body, they reveal the intentions of living beings. The universality of emotions is assessed by the recognition of facial expressions across different cultures; it generates so-called "basic" emotions that are universally shared (such as fear, anger, surprise, disgust, joy and sadness). The interest of Darwin's work [1872] is to codify on an empirical level a rigorous method of evaluating facial expressions that will be deepened by psychologists and biologists a century later (Ekman and Davidson [1994], Plutchik [1984]) and then used by modern facial recognition technologies (in particular for so-called "basic" or "universal" emotions (Ekman [1999]). Darwin [1872] thus marks the starting point of the scientific study of emotion. The biological vision of emotion is supported, in the 1880s, by what appears to be the first true psychological theory of emotion, known as the "James-Lange" theory. Darwin was interested in the expressive aspects.

The psychologist William James, unanimously recognized as the father of American psychology, and the anatomist Carl Lange, propose an analysis that is certainly in line with the English naturalist, but which provides an explanation of the psychological mechanisms underlying emotion.
James-Lange's thesis is as revolutionary as it is counter-intuitive.

These authors put forward the idea that physiological and bodily changes, as well as the behaviors associated with them, are not the "consequence" of emotion (as common sense and classical approaches of the time claim) but the "cause". According to this conception, becoming aware of these physiological changes constitutes the emotion in itself. For example, when we realize that we are in danger, this perception triggers a set of bodily responses and it is our awareness of these responses that constitutes fear.
This is what James [1884] sums up by saying that "we are sad because we cry" or that "we are afraid because we find that we tremble."

triplets.head: James
triplets.tail: we are sad because we cry

triplets.head: James
triplets.tail: we are afraid because we find that we tremble

text: Trembling is therefore not the result of emotion, its manifestation, it is its initial cause. James-Lange's theory has had a singular career.

On the one hand, it quickly became the highly visible "flag" of a nascent psychological science. On the other hand, it spontaneously underwent numerous criticisms and was unable to lead to a proposal that would achieve consensus within the scientific community.

In particular, for Cannon [1927], the main opponent of the so-called "peripheralist" theory (allusion to the fact that the source of emotion comes from bodily manifestations located on the periphery), the latter cannot distinguish what relates to emotion and what is dissociated from it, is incapable of differentiating emotions from each other (intense joy, great fear or great sadness generating the same bodily modifications), and finally gives disproportionate weight to the bodily component to the detriment of cognitive aspects.

Cannon [1927] then states a central theory of emotion which posits that its seat resides where no one had yet located it, that is to say, in the regions situated under the cerebral cortex (called "subcortical") and, in particular, at the level of the "thalamus".

From these regions originate parallel innervations that trigger physiological responses on the one hand and subjective emotional experience on the other. The interest of the “James-Lange” proposition and the work of its opponents is to fuel the debate on the nature of the relationship between emotion and cognition throughout the 20th century. It will find, in part, its resolution in the work of Schachter [1964] who adds to the “physiological arousal” specific to emotion a “cognitive labeling”, dependent on the context, and thus allows to admit the undifferentiated aspect of physical manifestations. As we see later, this marks the explicit beginning of cognitive and psychosocial theories of emotions (2.2). Another issue – concerning the primacy (or not) of emotion over cognition – will also feed the renewal of psychological theories of emotion in the 1980s. The presupposition of social psychologist Robert Zajonc is that the first reaction to an object or a person is an emotional (adaptive) reaction that can lead to a cognitive reaction. While for cognitive psychologist Richard Lazarus, cognition is a necessary condition for emotion and would therefore come first. The misunderstanding ultimately concerns how to define cognition.

triplets.head: James-Lange proposition
triplets.tail: debate on the nature of the relationship between emotion and cognition

text: For Emmanuel Petit———————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————— 185 REP 132 (2) March-April 2022Zajonc [1980], it designates a set of deliberate, rational and conscious processes while for Lazarus et al.

[1980], and for many other researchers, cognition can be rapid, uncontrollable and unconscious. This brings us back to the unconscious influences of emotion and to the central role that psychoanalysis and psychiatry (Sigmund Freud, Pierre Janet, Henri Wallon) played in this area at the beginning of the last century (see Channouf [2004]). Recent work in neuroscience is in line with the biological and psychological approaches that we have discussed so far. In fact, neurologists locate emotions in the brain (and more broadly in the body) and agree on a universalist and naturalist dimension of emotion. However, they insist on the links existing between the component of emotion inscribed in the body and its cognitive extension in the brain: this aims in particular at taking into account the intention specific to the emotion as well as its memorial or temporal dimension.
Damasio [1995] fully embodies this renewal.

In the theory he proposes, the individual begins by unconsciously apprehending the relevant elements of a situation or those of his close environment, which provokes cerebral reactions as well as peripheral or vagal modifications. As in James [1884], it is when he becomes aware of these reactions that the individual becomes aware of the emotion. According to Damasio [1995], when a similar situation arises, it evokes the central cerebral representations of the body image linked to these peripheral modifications. These representations thus play the role of "somatic markers" which allow, when we are again faced with similar situations or events, to immediately become aware of the emotion, and to associate with it traits of appropriate action behaviors. The marker would therefore function as an emotional memory, an emotional labeling of the event or landscape, as a warning or encouragement signal (innate or acquired) of cognitive and unconscious origin. Damasio's thesis [1995] found a very favorable echo in the academic world because it managed to convincingly overturn the preconceived idea that emotions would be a disruptor of decision-making.
Ledoux [1998] is also one of those who have enabled the rehabilitation of emotions that we call “visceral”.

It shows that in emergency situations (fire, aggression, predation, etc.), our perception of danger first passes through our emotional brain (via the amygdala) before being redirected a quarter of a second later to the prefrontal cortex.

The existence of this short subcortical circuit allows the organism to react quickly to elementary configurations of emotional stimuli, in the absence of elaborate perception and recognition. Emotion, more than reason, is vital here. In fact, the rigid opposition between reason and emotion is no longer claimed by any of the theorists of emotion. We can no longer oppose reason and emotion, cognitive and volitional faculties on the one hand and bodily and unconscious affectivity on the other, as Western thought has done for centuries. Emotions, on the contrary, appear to be necessary for human beings to be able to pursue long-term planned activities, to be able to react adequately to events and to maintain with others the relationships without which no practical rationality is possible. They therefore have an impact that can be direct, but also indirect and unconscious, and which is very often useful for individual decision-making. 2.2.

The cognitive dimension of emotion In contrast to those who describe emotion entirely (or primarily) through its bodily and biological dimension, cognitive authors and philosophers of the mind go so far as to say that emotion is nothing other than a manifestation of thought. Schematically, this underlies the idea that, for an emotion to be provoked, the object on which the emotion bears must affect or involve the individual according to his or her life, experience, expectations, interests or objectives. Committed to the continuity of the cognitive turn in linguistics, the science of emotions experienced a profound renewal of its approaches in the second half of the 20th century.

Heir to Aristotle's thinking, initiated by Arnold [1960] and by the "cognitive-physiological" theory of Schachter [1964], the cognitive approach flourished from the beginning of the 1980s, bringing together psychologists (Nico Frijda, Herbert Simon, Andrew Ortony, Gerald Clore and Allan Collins, Keith Oatley and Philip Johnson-Laird), but also influential philosophers (Ronald de Sousa, Robert Solomon, Jon Elster).

These authors share the idea that emotions are not passions that we passively undergo – Solomon [1976] notably denounced the “hydraulic” version of the physiological current of emotion – and affirm on the contrary that we are actively involved in their fabrication. The story begins with the proposition of Magda Arnold, a researcher of Austrian origin who emigrated to the United States, who relays the idea that perception is always the place of an encounter between a sensation and the expectations of a subject.

In this sense, perception is never neutral because it always involves a certain "coloring" of the subject's relationship to the object he perceives. This coloring is what Arnold [1960] calls an "appraisal" of the affective stimulation. Such an "appreciation" is manifested by an emotional attitude (disgust, fear, anger) that sets in almost as quickly as the perception itself, arousing nervous impulses from the cortex to the centers of the thalamus and the hypothalamus.
These centers in turn activate specific modules of facial expression, physiological changes and subjective experience.

A secondary evaluation phase then results from the awareness of these different changes that are evaluated as desirable or not. In this context, emotion is associated with a “tendency to action”, according to Frijda’s expression [1986], which is more a preparation for action (a potentiality) than an automatic behavior. Frijda [1986] here skillfully reconciles the phenomenological idea that emotions have an intentional aim (as suggested by Sartre [1938]) and the evolutionary conceptionEmmanuel Petit— ...
Guilt would thus incite us to repair (a wrong), desire to destroy (the desired object), fear would urge us to attack (the aggressor), to flee or even to faint.
A tendency to action can thus give rise (but not necessarily) to a whole range of differentiated behaviors depending on the situation.

This depends, if we follow Scherer [2005], on the nature of the evaluation process in progress: is the situation new, pleasant or unpleasant, in line with our objectives or not? In line with the theory of "evaluation" (Arnold [1960]), many authors (often philosophers) consider that emotions are more than a simple appreciation (of an event, of a behavior) or a moral judgment: they are also "revealers" of our values.

Livet [2002] defends in particular the idea that emotion results from the gap, the differential, between reality as we perceive it and our expectations, our preferences or our desires. The existence of this emotional differential provokes a necessary work of "revision" which aims to align our perception of the world with what the world tells us objectively. Emotion thus serves us, like an alarm signal, to re-evaluate our priorities in the medium term or to readjust our objectives when reality does not conform to what we expect of it. Emotion is a form of guide that allows us to adapt to our environment, like “somatic markers” (Damasio [1995]). However, when we chronically and systematically resist this revision process, and the emotion repeats itself (whether it is disappointment, anger or any other emotion), it reveals to us the importance that we give to particular desires, beliefs or preferences, which in fact correspond to our most deeply rooted values ​​that we do not wish to give up. The dynamics of emotion generated by this gap between values ​​and perceived reality show that emotion can be a way of accessing the value systems of the individual (but also those of the group) by taking into account the resistance to change as well as the desire for change.  2.3. The social and cultural construction of emotion Overlooking (but also relying on) the philosophy of mind and cognitivism, some authors see emotion more as the expression of a socially and culturally constructed society. Emotion is here considered as a product of the social in the sense that society would manufacture the feelings and emotional behavior of individuals. Emotions are (certainly) dispositions connected to the body but the body itself is shaped by culture and the times.

triplets.head: Livet
triplets.tail: idea that emotion results from the gap

text: The major authors behind this position in the first half of the 20th century were, for the most part, sociologists (Gabriel Tarde, Gustave Le Bon, Vilfredo Pareto, Marcel Mauss, Émile Durkheim, Maurice Halbwachs and Georg Simmel), anthropologists (Franz Boas, Bronislaw Malinowski, Ruth Benedict, Mar-188—————————— Theory of Emotions and Economic Analysis: A Review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022garet Mead) and philosophers (such as John Dewey), without forgetting of course the historians of the Annales who, in the 1930s, inaugurated the history of “sensitivities” (Febvre [1941]). Then, from the 1960s, “constructivist” authors – anthropologists, ethnologists, sociologists, political scientists, etc.

– have themselves provided support for cognitive approaches to emotion that have effectively fought, as we have seen, the idea that emotion cannot be reduced to the sole perception of peripheral modifications as proposed by the “James-Lange” theory at the end of the 19th century. The culturalist movement is markedly (and sometimes radically) opposed to the naturalist vision of emotion, inherited from the Darwinian tradition.
Anthropologists Jean Briggs, Catherine Lutz and Michelle Rosaldo are pioneers here.
According to Lutz [1988], in particular, “emotional experience is not precultural, but primarily cultural” (cited in Corbin et al.

triplets.head: Lutz
triplets.tail: emotional experience is not precultural, but primarily cultural

text: 21, emphasis added].

These precursors were supported by contemporary approaches that declined in various forms the anthropology of the sensitive (Françoise Héritier, François Laplantine) but also by historians of emotions who integrate the anthropological dimension like William Reddy. In sociology, the "interactionist" thought of Erving Goffman [1974], extended (in part) by Arlie Hochschild [2017], but also by Pierre Bourdieu, as well as the approach of psychologists James Averill, RomHarré or Bernard Rimé, illustrate this circumvention of the "organicist" conception of emotion. In the sociological and anthropological approach to emotions, it is the group that must be considered as a priority when we question the formation of individual emotions. A first key idea can be summarized by saying that the social constrains, in a deterministic way, the emotions of individuals and their way of behaving. These are, in other words, the ritual practices, the codes, the norms, the “rules of feelings”, which dictate the emotional behaviors typical of a culture or a collective (Mauss [1921]).
As Halbwachs [2014, p.
42], “there is in us a social man […] who watches over the passionate man”.

Emotions thus play a fundamental role in the socialization of individuals because they are permanently subject to a collective framework which, by coordinating individual behavior, guarantees the group the conformity of all to collective rules. The institutions of a society (family, religion, state, market) guide the emotional repertoire of individuals: they value certain attitudes and stigmatize others. Every society, every nation, has its own emotional codes which exert a strong influence on what people feel and on the way they feel. Benedict [1946] was thus the first to characterize Japanese culture as a "culture of shame". A culture which values ​​respect, love of one's neighbor, honor, loyalty, self-control. In Japan, social dignity consists above all in blending into the group.

Laplantine[2017] has highlighted a contrasting, heterogeneous country, where behaviors based on reserve, restraint, discretion, and impassivity coexist with others expressing a completely different emotional register based on exaltation, unreason, rage, or anger.Emmanuel Petit— ...

triplets.head: behaviors
triplets.tail: others expressing a completely different emotional register

text: These codes are gradually spreading through numerous institutions which relay them to individuals.

The rules relating to emotions are thus taught and learned within the family, at school, at university, at work, but also in the army, in the Church and, naturally, through political action and discourse.
This is particularly the case with fear of authority (obedience) or respect for hierarchy.
In Bourdieu, emotion thus appears not only as a product of the social but also as a mechanism for the reproduction of inequalities (see Emirbayer et al.

It is in particular the power relationship (dominant/dominated) that is experienced in emotion by directly influencing the "sense of place" (comfort or discomfort) that one occupies in the social sphere. Following the work of Goffman [1974], we understand that the game of deﬁguration of emotion depends closely on social position and constrains those who, at the lowest level of the hierarchical ladder, are concerned about the way the dominants look at them. According to Bourdieu, these mechanisms of reproduction of emotional codes are the result of a socialization strongly charged with emotion that begins in the child and is perpetuated, in the form of affective habitus, in the adult. Emotions, like tastes, are determined by status, social itinerary and fueled by the recurrence of typical situations linked to economic and social conditions of existence (Emirbayer et al. [2005]). The second important idea in the social construction of emotion is that the way we perceive our emotions (and those of others) has a central cultural dimension. In other words, many emotions are felt differently depending on the culture in which they are expressed. Moreover, in all cultures, these emotions are interpreted from a naive theory of emotion to which individuals subscribe and fully adhere.

For example, the theory of "humors" known since Antiquity, which inspired the obsolete practice of bloodletting in the 16th and 17th centuries, has long influenced the world of letters and the arts and still finds its reminiscence today in the temperaments that we call "sanguineous", "phlegmatic" or "bilious".
This naive theory includes the various scripts in force in the individual's culture as well as all the common sense considerations relating to thoughts, bodily sensations or behavioral inclinations.

In Ecuador, for example, sadness is manifested by a painful headache accompanied by heart palpitations (Le Breton [2004]) while in Belgium, it corresponds to a lump in the throat and gastrointestinal sensations (Rimé et al.

[1990]). Ethnological studies clearly show that the emotions of other cultures involve – and are based on – theories of emotion very different from those that the Western dualistic vision has been promoting for centuries.

Outside the Western world, the individual's sensitive and cognitive faculties are not separate or opposed. On the contrary, they are considered as part of a totality, a unity, belonging to the same part of the being and constituting a single activity relating to social relations.

For example, among the T’ai Dam, a community living in northern Laos, the heart appears above all as a relational organ (Collomb190—————————— Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022[2011]): it is through it, but also with the body, that we learn and know.

triplets.head: Collomb
triplets.tail: Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review

text: Where a French person says "I don't know what's going through his head", a T'ai Dam says rather "I don't know what's going on in his heart" Collomb [2011, p.

To agree with someone is to “be of the same heart”; to decide is to “decide with [the] heart”.  In reaction to the “biological” or “hydraulic” current (Solomon [1976]), social and culturalist approaches reveal that emotional states do not always arise spontaneously from our interiority. They are the fruit of work that we carry out, often unconsciously, in order to agree with the “rules of feelings” or the “rules of expression” in force in our social environment.  2.4.

The general picture that emerges The scientific study of emotions covers a very wide range of approaches associating many academic disciplines. Some emphasize the individual, bodily and cognitive dimension of emotion. Others insist on the social and collective aspects of the emotional process. Historically, the major disciplines of emotion (biology, psychology, philosophy, sociology, anthropology) have often been constructed in a compartmentalized manner, neglecting or minimizing the contributions of other disciplinary fields. The bridges between disciplines have in fact long remained tenuous.

However, recent work seems to announce a convergence (more than a consensus) of these different analyses which would allow us to benefit, in an interdisciplinary logic, from their differentiated contributions (Verweij et al.
Two important ideas illustrating this convergence emerge from this general picture.

The first suggests that cognition is “embodied.” The second suggests that emotion is a revealer and a driver of our relationship to the world. “Embodied” cognition refers to the idea that thought is inseparable from the body.

text: "A man who thinks is an affected man" (Le Breton [2004], p.626].

triplets.head: A man who thinks is an affected man

text: A whole series of analyses and propositions thus attest to the harmonious or non-disjointed functioning between reason and emotion.
The individual, constantly affected by events, by objects or by those around him, constructs a bodily memory which is activated in cognitive processes.
Varela et al.

[2017] assert for example that bodily functions (sensory and motor) are integral components of the mind and not secondary elements at its service: the body is an integral part of cognition in the sense that we think and feel things based on what happens in our sensory and motor systems.

For the brain to produce meaning, it must have a history, act on its environment, and observe its variations. The second idea extends the body/mind interaction we have just seen and takes full account of the extent of the individual's relationship with their environment.

More precisely, emotion is conceivedEmmanuel Petit—————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————— 191 REP 132 (2) March-April 2022as a relationship in the sense that it reveals the qualities of the relationship that we have with objects, with nature, with ourselves or with others (Laﬂamme [1995]).
By establishing the relationship, by composing it, emotion is the mediator, the operator, capable of making or unmaking it.
It therefore constitutes an important source of change and social transformation (Petit [2021a]). 3.

The place of emotion in economic analysis: behavior, society, institutions The introduction of emotions into economic analysis is a particularly recent phenomenon in light of the construction of the theory of emotions mentioned in the first part of our review. Favoring the analysis of individual behavior, the experimental and behavioral approach in economics (3.1) has mobilized a psychological and bio-logical conception (2.1 and 2.2) that describes emotion essentially as an autonomous or purely internal phenomenon. On the other hand, economic sociology (3.2) has drawn on the achievements of the sociological and anthropological approach to emotions (2.3) in order to show how social and cultural dynamics shape the emotional attitudes of individuals. For institutional economics (3.3), if the introduction of emotions remains a relatively unexplored field (Patalano [2010]), recent work reveals why emotion plays a major role in the transformation of institutions via modifications of individual behaviors. 3.1.
The experimental and behavioral approach 3.1.1.

Contributions and perspectives As we initially pointed out, the introduction of emotions into economic analysis has been carried out mainly from experimental and behavioral economics (Petit [2009, 2015]). Experimental economists rely on the approaches in psychology and neuroscience that we mentioned previously (2.1 and 2.2).

triplets.head: Petit
triplets.tail: introduction of emotions into economic analysis

text: They use a functional definition of emotion.
This has an intensity and a valence (associated with usefulness), a tendency to action (assimilated to individual behavior) and a facial expression (integrated as a signal of an intention).

When the emotions mobilized by decision-makers192—————————— Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022have a strong cognitive scope – as is the case, for example, with a counterfactual emotion such as regret – economists draw on theories of emotion in cognitive or social psychology. In this context, they mobilize many “heuristics” (such as that of affectivity) or behavioral biases (such as the conﬁrmation bias) mentioned by psychologists to identify the role of emotion in decision-making. In terms of methodology and the use of experimental tools, economists have also relied on psychology and neuroscience to induce certain types of emotions in the laboratory and obtain a viable and precise measurement of the intensity of emotions and moods felt or perceived by individuals. Mood induction methods, personality tests, Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI), measurements of facial expressions or even the subjective assessment of emotions, etc., are now part of the classic tools of experimental economists.

Let us cite, among many others, the pioneering work of Capra [2004] on mood induction, the more recent work of Drouvelis and Grosskopf [2016] reproducing a similar technique in a public good game in the presence of sanctions, and finally that of Proto et al.

[2019] showing, from a lexical study of communication between players before the start of a repeated prisoner's dilemma game, that participants in a "good mood" statistically cooperate less than participants in a neutral mood. The case of regret illustrates the fruitful progress made by economists in this work of introducing affects into their corpus. Regret is indeed one of the first emotions to have been integrated (along with envy, no doubt).
On the experimental level, first of all, through the specific role it occupies in the “resolution” of the famous Allais paradox (see Petit [2015, p.

At the modeling level, then, with the now well-identified theory of “regret minimization” by Loomes and Sugden [1982] and the work in applied behavioral finance identifying the disposition effect (Shefrin and Statman [1983]). More recent work on regret also reveals the connection, complementarity and close collaboration – object of study, definition, measurement, experimental method, implications – that exists, around decision-making, between psychologists (Zeelenberg et al.
[2002]) and economists (Coricelli et al. [2007]).

Finally, regret is still the subject of active and fruitful research in behavioral and experimental economics, which testifies more than seventy years after the exploratory beginnings on regret of its research potential. Bourgeois-Gironde [2017], for example, attempts to make the link between the individual neurological underpinnings of the emotion of regret and collective regrets – foreshadowing and announcing a central issue (to which we return in the conclusion of this review) around the transition from individual emotion to collective emotion – while other works extend the first attempts at modeling by integrating the contributions of the psychological theory of regret (Gabillon [2020]). Based on standard neoclassical theory, the introduction of emotions into experimental and behavioral economics has had, according to Petit [2015], three notable consequences. First of all, it allowed us to dismantleEmmanuel Petit— ... Second important consequence: by introducing a plurality of emotions – and in particular those with a positive valence (such as gratitude or pride) – economists have been led to downplay the scope of individual selfishness (see Jourdheuil and Petit [2015] for a review) and to question more about the choice procedure in the presence of moral or ethical dilemmas (Rustichini [2018]). The diversity of (moral) emotions and the emphasis on the role of empathy (Thoron [2017]) have thus led to highlighting the plurality of human motivations – whether trust, reciprocity, cooperation or a sense of fairness – while also showing the major role of context in the emergence of these social or moral preferences.
Finally, taking emotions into account has also had an impact on the way economic policies are designed, through “emotional paternalism” (Thunström et al.
[2018]) or what is more generally called the “nudge” (Thaler and Sunstein [2010]).

While regulating or suppressing emotions is often an ineffective solution (Lerner et al. [2015]), modifying the “choice architecture” (i.e. the environment in which the decision is made) seems to be a promising avenue. Since these first elements of review (Petit [2015]), the works integrating emotions have (most often) extended these approaches (Dunning et al. [2017]), reinforced the place of emotions in the modeling of psychological games (Karpouzis and Yannakakis [2016], Battigalli and Dufwenberg [2020]), highlighted original emotions such as curiosity, spite, frustration, disgust, surprise, joy or even suspense (Gomes [2017]), explored new questions (Halladay [2017], Ibanez et al. [2017], van der Swaluw et al.
[2018], Wang et al.

[2018], Lechner and Paul [2019], Souche-Le Corvec and Zhao [2020], Ginsburgh and Weber [2020]), or have used new experimental procedures (Takagishi et al. [2014], Gomes [2017], Hopfensitz and Mantilla [2019]).
Souche-Le Corvec and Zhao [2020], for example, renew the question of the economics of transport by relying on neural data on emotion.

Originally, Ginsburgh and Weber [2020] trace how language modifies modes of thought and emotional expression in order to study the effects and repercussions of linguistic differences, particularly on trade, migration or financial markets.
Ibanez et al.
[2017] study the impact of “incidental” emotions 4such as amusement or surprise mixed with fear on donation behaviors to pro-environmental associations.
Halladay [2017] highlights the original impact of 4.
“Incidental” emotions are emotions triggered by events that are unrelated to the decision at hand (see Lerner et al.

They differ from so-called "integral" emotions, which are linked to the decision that the individual makes (such as the fear that one experiences when making risky investments).194—————————— Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022gender and emotion (with negative valence) on performance in a competitive game.

Similarly, using commercial facial recognition software and an extensive database of several thousand player portraits, Hopfensitz and Mantilla [2019] observe that football teams whose players display the most obvious anger (or joy) are those that concede (score) the most (fewest) goals. 3.1.2.

Methodological limits: the case of the emotion of fear Despite these recent contributions, the introduction of emotion into the behavioral economic approach still constitutes a major epistemological obstacle.

Hope, for example, which plays a fundamental role in intertemporal choices, is almost absent from economic theory (Pecchenino [2011]). Hope and fear form a separate class in the categories proposed by Elster [1998]: they are emotions that are generated by the thought that something could happen.

Like hope, the representation of fear constitutes a real challenge for economists (Cedrini and Novarese [2015]). Indeed, few proponents of behavioral economics directly evoke fear in their work. 5. In fact, despite the pioneering work of Keynes [1936], Boulding [1973] and the more recent work of Pope [1985, 2015], the word “fear” is almost absent from the vocabulary of economists, particularly in experimental and behavioral economics (see, however, Ehrig et al.

When it is mobilized, it is in almost exclusive reference to the precautionary principle (not very popular with behaviorists (see Origgi [2014]) and to the "heuristic of fear" put forward by Jonas [1979] and, more recently, around the economic implications of stigmatization and/or terrorism (Schulze and Wansink [2012], Becker and Rubinstein [2011], Clark et al. [2020], Akay et al. [2020]). Fear is nevertheless one of the most studied and cited emotions in the academic literature. According to Bourke [2005], it is the most widespread emotion and, in particular, one of the dominant emotions during the health episode (Covid-19) that the world has been going through since spring 2020 (Kleinberg et al.

Fear manifests itself in various forms, ranging from anxiety, dread, worry, anguish, to fright, phobia, dread or even terror 6. In economic analysis, fear is essentially and almost exclusively perceived as a bias of rationality that distances the individual from 5.

Nelson [2015] thus notes (ironically) that Colin Camerer explicitly evokes the “fear” of economists on this subject, via an internet link (https://docsbay.net/why- are-economists-so-aversion-averse, consulted on June 24, 2020), while himself referring the reader to a working document whose title is much more cautious and neutral (“Threecheers – psychological, theoretical, empirical – for loss-aversion”). 6.

triplets.head: working document
triplets.tail: Threecheers – psychological, theoretical, empirical – for loss-aversion

text: Following Riezler [1944], we generally distinguish between “defined” fears, whose object is clearly located (fear of an identified aggressor, fear of unemployment), and those that are called “undefined”, whose source is not clearly identifiable, and which correspond more to anxiety or existential angst. Emmanuel Petit— ...
On a theoretical level, it has been understood as a sort of "background", with priority given to the development of a theory of risk to which economists give a more neutral character.
The economic analysis of uncertainty is in fact summed up as an aversion to risk by individuals capable of precisely representing the space of probabilities.

Their choice can therefore only be influenced by the emotions that result from the final outcome (once it is known), such as disappointment or regret, if the outcome is negative, or joy and excitement if it is not 7. The notion of risk therefore constitutes a comfortable – but also insufficient – ​​substitute for the more problematic notion of “fear” (Nelson [2015]). In the technical definition of risk, the sequential process of choice (risk-taking, experience of uncertainty, resolution phase) is eliminated, which amounts to removing the dynamic and emotional dimension characteristic of choice in the presence of uncertainty (Pope et al.
In the standard theory, only the resolution phase is preserved.
Academic risk theory thus creates the illusion of a predictable, measurable world, and of a real possibility of risk “management” (Hopkin [2018]).

Fear is not integrated into it. Certainly, work in behavioral economics has revisited the standard theory with some success by introducing a “meta-emotion” such as “fear of regret” (Shefrin and Statman [1985]), aversion to “loss” (Tversky and Kahneman [1991]) or to “ambiguity” (Al-Najjar and Weinstein [2009]), fear of the unknown or the unusual (Cao et al. [2011]), fear of “downgrading” (Jetten et al.
[2017]), the lack of “attention” (Falkinger [2008]) or even the anxious attitude of economic agents (Gambetti and Giusberti [2012], Wälde and Moors [2017]).

They also recognize a difference (fundamental for choices that affect the future) between the emotion that we anticipate and the "immediate" emotion that we actually experience when the time comes (Rick and Loewenstein [2008], Dunning et al.
[2017]). Behavioral economics, however, retains a strong rational framework.

It is assumed in particular that by informing individuals of the real risks they run in a given situation, they will avoid (too) risky situations or (on the contrary) will engage in them when the risk is measured.
Fear, however, cannot be grasped on a rational, probabilistic basis alone.

The existence of a dual neural circuit of fear (Ledoux[1998]) – one automatic and the other conscious – justifies, for example, that the same person can feel a particular fear in a tunnel or an elevator while being able to correctly estimate the low probability of risk in these distressing places.
Fear in fact actively mobilizes our unconscious somatic memory, it takes root in the body. Its adaptive interest consists precisely in our capacity to record and 7.

The founders of modern risk theory (von Neumann and Morgenstern [1944]) were well aware that the criterion of "expected utility" that they proposed did not take into account the emotions that come from the simple fact of "taking the risk". For example, a form of worry, annoyance, excitement, hope or even boredom.

What was perceived by these authors as a challenge to be taken up by the researchers who would succeed them has, however, remained a dead letter.196—————————— Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022to keep in mind for a long time the clues likely to warn us of future dangers.

Unlike other memories, fear-related memories are capable of not only eliciting a fear response but also of completely re-initiating the negative experience elicited by the initially threatening event.
A person who has had a car accident will learn to be wary of automobiles or risky driving and, if necessary, may develop fear of other potentially dangerous means of transportation.

The memory of fear can therefore be persistent because it is unconscious in nature. As suggested by work on “post-memory” (Hirsch [2017]), the emotional power of certain traumatic events (such as fratricidal wars or epidemics) is so strong that these events that occurred in the past see their effects continue unconsciously in the present within generations that did not experience them. A central question concerning fear is how an individual can regulate it, control it when its origin may be unconscious in nature.

Psychologists who work on these issues know that one cannot eliminate an emotion, that it is very complex to oust it or to "compensate" for it with another (as many philosophers proposed in the 18th century (see Hirschman [1977])) and that, in this matter, cognitive effort or even financial incentive are not very operational (Ler-ner et al.

Work in psychology has shown, for example, how difficult it can be to “decondition” a pathology linked to fear, such as intense stress induced by an episode of fright or various forms of phobias (Rimé [2015]).

The environment, institutions, and context play a central role here, promoting (or not) this learning. The approach of historians (Delumeau [1978], Robin [2008]) reminds us in particular of the weight of institutions in the social construction of fear. A climate of collective fear established by a particular event (September 11, 2001) can lead to the acceptance of public policies in different spheres of public or private life (Internet surveillance activity, restriction of mobility, freedoms and modes of expression, censorship, etc.), even if they are not linked to the original fear.
This is made possible because the initial emotion lastingly modifies the perception of individual risk (Lerner et al.
[2003]). To counteract the effects of fear, it is therefore not a question of avoiding risk at all times but of cultivating it (Pope et al.

[2006]), not to rely on “expert systems” which deprive individuals of the experience of decision-making, or even not to fully engage our resources (economic, human, emotional, military) and our organizational systems, in anticipation of a hazard, a crisis (economic or health).
“Getting out of the empire of fear” (Delumeau [1978]) is therefore more about knowing it and taming it. 3.1.3.

triplets.head: Getting out of the empire of fear
Delumeau
triplets.tail: Getting out of the empire of fear

text: Progress report Based on a psychological and biological reading of emotion, experimental and behavioral economics has effectively integrated theEmmanuel Petit— ...
This is the case, in particular, as we have emphasized, of a cognitive emotion such as regret.
The analyses and methods initially envisaged (Petit[2015]) have been extended and expanded.

As we have however mentioned regarding the emotion of fear, the behavioral approach is limited by a conception of emotion which is limited to the description of a psychological state and which does not integrate (or barely) the social, historical or cultural aspects specific to the emotion. Pecchenino’s recent contribution [2011, 2015] – drawing in particular on philosophical, theological and psychological conceptions of hope (and its antithesis, despair) – shows, however, that it is possible to model the main characteristics of this counterfactual emotion: hope holds out the prospect of a possibility, of accessible objectives; it notably accentuates the value of the future (in relation to the present), is not irrational from the moment when the individual is capable of correctly filtering the information transmitted to him, represents a force for change (at the level of the individual and society) as well as an ability to mobilize individual effort; hope also depends crucially on the quality of the social bond (the absence of which can, on the contrary, give rise to despair). This reading of hope – from which, in our opinion, useful lessons can be extracted in the context of the health crisis that humanity has been experiencing since the beginning of 2020 – shows that the initial reductive conception of emotion in behavioral economics can be overcome. Similarly, the innovative approach proposed by Thoron [2017] – which emphasizes the relational capacity of emotion – or that of van Winden [2012, 2015] – which insists on the existence of affective-social links between agents (see Petit [2018] for a review) – indicate a possible overcoming (or extension) of this initial orientation. This extension can notably be inspired, in the field of economic analysis, by other approaches that have explored the question of emotions, as is the case in economic sociology (3.2) or the economics of institutions (3.3). 3.2. Economic sociology or the control of emotions The rejection of pure rationality and the absence of consideration of the social and culture constitute unifying elements of the sociological approach to emotions (2.3). This approach has benefited from the founding works around the sociology of rituals (Parsons [1937]), interactionist thought (Goffman [1974]), relational sociology (Laflamme [1995]) or even the anthropological communication approach (Bateson [1991]) (see Berezin [2006] and Bernard [2017] for reviews).
In support of this literature, economic sociology has integrated emotion in order to explore new questions (Etzioni [1988]; Pixley [2002, 2012]).

Barbalet [2009], for example, describes the effects of emotion on trust. Flam [2002] analyzes the existence of an emotional culture within organizations198—————————— Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022while Hassoun [2005] shows the specificity of traders' emotions on financial markets. Two themes bring together a large part of this literature (mainly carried by sociologists) which starts from the principle that individual emotions are shaped by society. One questions the control, imposed by the market and companies, of employees' emotions (3.2.1). The other highlights the way in which the market itself produces and sells emotion (3.2.2). 3.2.1. Emotions under control During the 20th century, the development of capitalism led to the development of an entrepreneurial culture that gave a central place to emotional life in companies and organizations. By integrating affects, economic logic transformed the traditional divisions – reason/emotion, public/private, masculine/feminine – that had prevailed until then. In the mid-1930s, the scientific approach to regulating emotions met with a very strong demand from companies wishing to develop worker performance.

triplets.head: Hassoun
triplets.tail: specificity of traders' emotions on financial markets

text: Mayo [1933] is a pioneer here: he conducted a famous experiment in the Western Electric Company factories in Hawthorne from 1924 to 1927, which revealed that employee productivity increased when work relations took into account the workers' emotions.
Mayo opens the way to a period in which the economic sphere can no longer be considered an emotional desert.

Corporate culture gradually integrates human relations, self-enhancement techniques, emotional control and measurement, various communication tools, in order to establish a climate of trust, cooperation or a sense of belonging to the institution (Illouz [2009]). Since that time, the process of controlling employees' emotions has continued to grow. The concept of "emotional intelligence", highlighted by Goleman [1998], has thus become, within the company, a classic instrument for classifying (and therefore hierarchizing) employees' emotional skills, which partly determines their access to responsibilities, the advancement procedure concerning them, the bonuses to which they are entitled as well as the definition of their organizational role.
However, today we no longer talk about “control” but more about regulation or listening to one’s emotions.

Personal development cultivated within the company itself contributes greatly to this self-regulation. It is supervised by “soul managers” (Brunel [2016]) who promote the idea of ​​self-realization and individual freedom.
We praise the virtues of autonomy, of “letting go” and of fulfillment at work.
Joy, play, complicity, etc., are popular.
Employee well-being has thus become the key to understanding the new management of human resources at the beginning 8.

Emotional intelligence is a form of social intelligence that includes the ability to control one’s own emotions and those of others, to distinguish between these emotions, and to use this information to guide one’s thoughts and actions.Emmanuel Petit— ...
Well-being and pleasure at work are, however, at the service of an efficiency objective.

Lordon [2013] sees in recent managerial psychology the awareness, within the productive system, that it is more profitable to govern by joy than by fear. Capitalism has found a use for the management of emotions and has organized it effectively.

This particularly concerns a category of service professions (secretaries, nurses, cashiers, etc.) in which “emotional work” – the (forced) smile of the flight attendant or cashier, the sobriety of the undertaker, the (feigned) joviality of the shopkeeper or secretary – is used by companies and directed towards commercial ends (Hochschild [2017]).

Emotion management is done by promoting a “genuine” smile, by training employees to produce such a smile, by supervising their production, and even by creating a link between this “activity” and the profit that companies generate. Those who perform emotional labor when they provide a service are, just like those who perform physical labor by manufacturing objects, subject to the same rules of mass production.
From then on, the “house is no longer a refuge against the abuses linked to the search for profit, and for its part, the market relies on the imaginary of the house” (Hochs-child [2017, p.
177]), as when airlines use the idea that stewardesses are “like a family” in the aircraft cabin and that the emotions they are supposed to experience there are of the same nature.

Economic sociology thus highlights the potential social and psychological consequences induced by “emotional work”, which sometimes results in professional exhaustion. 3.2.2. Emotions for sale It may seem strange that we can attribute a price to emotion and that affectivity is itself a commercial issue. Jeudy-Ballini [2004] nevertheless mentioned the existence of a “price” for the expression of emotion within the Sulka community in Papua New Guinea: when a sulka intentionally provokes a negative emotion (anger, shame, etc.) in another, the latter is expected to claim material compensation. The most paradoxical thing is that, even in the presence of an emotion with a positive valence (such as admiration or delight), the emotional impact induced – for example, in a spectator by the beauty of a mask, a song or a dance – can be the subject of a request for compensation as soon as the person experiencing it makes a statement about it (Derlon and Jeudy-Ballini [2008]). In the market system, such a price does not exist. However, it is easy to understand that a poker player who has poor control over his emotions at a table will quickly lose a lot of money.

triplets.head: Jeudy-Ballini
triplets.tail: a “price” for the expression of emotion

text: More generally, managers have long shown that expressions of emotions have a significant impact on the outcome of negotiations (Morris and Keltner [2000]), as can be the case in particular with anger (Sinaceur and Tie-dens [2006]), sadness (Sinaceur et al. [2015]) or even when the negotiator's emotions are unpredictable (Sinaceur et al.

Similarly, we can consider that emotional work, if it is valued by companies, corresponds to a cost integrated into the service or product intended for consumers or users. Since companies have oriented emotional work towards commercial ends, the latter have largely become accustomed to the play of superficial emotions that characterize the social or professional environment.
Even though it is often a fairly inauthentic work, it is appreciated by the public for which it is intended and valued as such.

One of the challenges of expressing emotions through artificial intelligence or robots lies precisely in the bet of this valorization of emotion (Robinson and Kaliouby [2009], Petit [2021b]). To these (non-exhaustive) elements of valorization must be added the fact (studied relatively recently) that emotion is now for sale in the commercial sphere in the form of an "affective experience" (Fil-ser [2015]).
A significant part of marketing activities is geared towards an “experiential” design of the good or service offered.

The “forager” is thus someone who comes to a point of sale, without the intention of purchasing, in search of a pleasurable experience (for example, to discover new things, to mingle with the crowd or even simply to touch, listen or taste).

The tourism sector perfectly illustrates this dimension in the sense that traveling, at the beginning of the 21st century, means looking for moments that are as emotionally intense as they are memorable (Veneyre[2016]).
To travel is to have an “authentic” experience, it is to be amazed.

Finally, but this time in a more critical but also more extensive manner, Illouz [2019] denounces the excesses of the expansion of the market into the intimate sphere – as Zelizer [2000] initially did – by noting that if the purchase of goods allows one to “experience” emotions, the emotions themselves have been transformed into goods. 3.3.

The contribution of the institutionalist approach: cognition and emotion The institutionalist project highlights the role of institutions in economic analysis – their formation as well as their transformation – and starts from a conception of the human that goes beyond both his interest and his pure reason (Chavance [2018]). This project thus aims to introduce a process – emotion – which is (1) a connection between the individual and institutions, (2) which transforms both in a dynamic and continuous way and which, moreover (3) is capable of doing so in a non-conscious way as we have underlined in the first part of this review. 3.3.1. The intuitions of the founders In the works of the founders of institutionalism at the beginning of the 20th century – whether Thorstein Veblen or John Commons – emotion has been relatively little mobilized.
Certainly, Veblen repeatedly appeals to instincts (Hodgson [2007], Almeida [2015]) while Emmanuel Petit— ...
Thus, according to Commons [1934, p.
390, our emphasis], man "is originally a being of passion [...] for whom freedom and reason are a matter of the slow evolution of moral character and the constraint imposed by government."

At the time, the accumulated knowledge on the question of emotions probably did not allow these authors to go further. In the 1950s, however, progress in cognitive psychology (see 2.2.) would encourage reflection on the scope of emotion.

triplets.head: progress in cognitive psychology
triplets.tail: reflection on the scope of emotion

text: Two of the major references of the "new institutional economics" - Herbert Simon and Friedrich Hayek - have thus developed a relevant and elaborate analysis of the role of emotion in the human mind.

triplets.head: Herbert Simon
triplets.tail: analysis of the role of emotion

triplets.head: Friedrich Hayek
triplets.tail: analysis of the role of emotion

text: Inspired in particular by Gestalt, Hayek [1952] proposes, in The Sensory Order, a theory of the mind that mobilizes sensory perceptions as much as the emotions of individuals. Hayek [1952] anticipates in particular the progress of contemporary cognitive sciences (and in particular connectionism) on which the "cognitive" approach of the institutions of Denzau and North [1994] will be based.
Simon [1967] has been widely identified in the literature for his contribution to a "limited" conception of rationality.

He is, however, one of the first authors to foresee that a complete theory of human rationality must include emotions (Kaufman [1999]). Announcing the advances in neurology (Damasio [1995]), Simon [1967] sees in the emotional process an alarm signal that allows us to revise our priorities in the medium term or to readjust our objectives (see 2.1). 3.3.2.

Emotion, a missing piece of the approach of the new institutional economics The interest of the new institutional economics carried by Douglass North and his colleagues (Denzau and North [1994], Mantzavinos et al.

[2004], North [2005]) has been to propose coherent “cognitive foundations” for the theory of institutions. In particular, it involves thinking about the way in which individual beliefs (and in particular ideology) play a dynamic role in the formation of institutions and, in return, understanding how the latter modify beliefs. The belief system is thus, according to North [2005], a central determinant of economic development. Mantzavinos et al.

76] were well aware that the mental model they proposed was a first (essential) step in establishing a relationship between individual beliefs and the institutions that result from them. In their model, emotions promote the strengthening of the belief system when it has proven effective in the past. Emotions therefore reinforce beliefs and, in doing so, contribute to their stability.
Initially, Denzau and North [1994, p.

20] had themselves underlined the connoted “affective” scope of certain terms – such as “worker” or “capitalist” – within Marxist ideology. However, it is in North [2005] that we find the most striking clues of the role that emotion could play in their model. North202—————————— Theory of Emotions and Economic Analysis: A Review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022[2005, p. 63] first explicitly mentions and cites Antonio Damasio (see 2.1), according to whom “consciousness and emotions cannot be separated”.

triplets.head: North
triplets.tail: Theory of Emotions and Economic Analysis: A Review

triplets.head: Theory of Emotions and Economic Analysis: A Review

text: Further, quoting biologist Gerald Edelman on the link between language and thought, North [2005, p.

65] mentions – without however drawing the consequences – the great scope of the last part of Edelman’s quote: “it must be remembered that, because of its link with values ​​and the concept of self, this system of meaning is almost never free of affects: it is charged with emotions”. Despite their intuitions and the mobilization of authors such as Simon, Hayek – or even Polanyi [1962] around “implicit knowledge” – institutionalist authors in fact grant a very secondary place to emotion in their modeling (Patalano [2010]). As we have however underlined in the first part of our review, emotion could be mobilized upstream – as a determining element in the formation of beliefs, attitudes and values ​​(Livet [2002]).

It can also be an element of rupture and creativity, and have an impact on the formation of institutions. However, it is within the framework of work in organizational theory (initiated by managers) that these elements have been developed recently. 3.3.3. Institutions and emotions in organizational theory A significant part of the literature in organizational theory seeks to explain the microeconomic foundations of institutions. In this context, many studies have identified the major role played by emotions (Zietsma and Toubiana [2018]).
These participate in particular in the process of institutionalization of individuals because they are at the heart of the process of adhesion or affiliation to these institutional structures.
Emotions are thus the basis of moral judgment, of the feeling of "what is right" (or not), which conditions belonging to a social group or respect for a standard of solidarity (Lok et al.

triplets.head: feeling of what is right
triplets.tail: respect for a standard of solidarity

text: Emotions therefore contribute to the formation of institutions. They also represent – ​​as is the case for anger or indignation – a force for change in these institutions (Ibidem). In return, however, institutions shape the emotional expressions of the individuals who are part of them.

In certain corporations – such as justice, the army, but also for example “gourmet cuisine” (Gillet Burrows [2018] – emotions (such as fear or shame) are used to shape the attitudes and behaviors of individuals.
In summary, as Zietsma and Toubiana [2018, p.

436], "[e]motions connect us to institutions, but they are often also what distinguishes and defines institutions." Organizational theory also brings an innovative perspective by taking up the idea of ​​a "relational" emotion mentioned in the first part of our review (see 2.4).
Friedland [2018] thus defines institutions as “modes of behavior”.
Emotions are not only reactions to institutional structures, theyEmmanuel Petit— ...

This implies in particular that if our emotions closely connect us to institutions, it is the change in emotional attitudes that can promote their mutation. 3.3.4. Perspectives The integration of emotions into the study of institutions is, for economists, a recent issue.

If, for example, the evolutionary and mechanical approach of Winter [2017] – which defines emotion only in opposition to reason – reveals the minor place that can sometimes be attributed to it (see however Bowles and Gintis [2011]), the contribution of Markey-Towler [2018] seems much more promising.
Markey-Towler [2018] returns to the pre-psychological conditions that must exist for institutions to determine behavior.

In particular, it highlights the role that emotions play in conformity to institutions. In this sense, his approach is inspired by the sociological approach to emotions (2.3) but also by the theory of organizations that we have just mentioned (3.3.3) as well as the model of Denzau and North [1994]. The conceptualization work of Markey-Towler [2018] thus shows that there is a potential for introducing emotion into the institutionalist approach that is based on the intersection of related literatures. 4. Scope and challenges of the economics of emotions for the discipline Our review of the literature on the introduction of the theory of emotions into economic analysis has shown that this abundant literature is now based on an open and multidisciplinary conception of emotion: to the conventional approaches of biology and psychology are added studies in the social and human sciences around sociology, anthropology but also history and naturally philosophy. Apprehended in a more global and more complete way, emotion has thus been introduced both in the field of experimental and behavioral economics but also progressively in economic sociology or by institutionalist authors. It thus emerges from our review that the most recent "economics of emotions" has largely benefited from an in-depth theoretical knowledge of the science of emotions. Emotion is thus no longer perceived as an alteration of reason.

triplets.head: Markey-Towler
triplets.tail: potential for introducing emotion into institutionalist approach

triplets.head: economics of emotions
triplets.tail: theoretical knowledge of the science of emotions

text: Its social and cultural dimension is recognized.

Its versatility – action on beliefs, behaviors or values ​​– is evident in many works. The diagnosis of the scope and usefulness of introducing emotions into economics cannot, however, be limited to this positive observation and must be204—————————— Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022examined more precisely.
In our review, we have sought to bring together a broad literature on this issue within standard economics, economic sociology and institutional economics.

Within these currents of analysis, the interest, and probably the usefulness for the discipline, of introducing emotion is of a rather different nature. In economic sociology, for example, the many works on emotions identify useful points of application for economists (the market of emotions or emotions in the market) as well as a notional basis (emotional intelligence, trust, management of emotions within the company, phenomena of exhaustion at work, social control of affect) often too little mobilized by standard theory.
This work usefully supports more conceptual or applied work.

In this sense, they reinforce economic analysis and can also be a source of inspiration. In behavioral economics, the challenge is more, around the question of decision-making, to experiment in order to better grasp the part of emotion in individual attitudes.
There is also a strong modeling issue, this being a trademark of the discipline in its most dominant component.

We have certainly identified the methodological limits of the standard approach based on the emotion of fear. The example of regret, however, shows how far we have come since the first exploratory works. It appears that behavioral economists favor a "discreet" (and often universal) (psychological) reading of emotion, identifying the effects of a particular emotion (envy, anger, guilt, etc.) based on a multi-component logic (Scherer [2005]). This is an undeniable asset but it is also a limitation of the analysis when, taking into account the polymorphic nature of emotion (we often make a parallel with color or music), it arises in a specific social and cultural context mixed with other affects (or even other emotions). For many of the problems they face, decision-makers often face a composite of emotions (anger, fear, disgust, resentment, empathy, etc.) that evolves very dynamically and in response to changes in the environment and the emotional changes of others.

The contribution of behavioral economics is therefore reduced since it is based on an exclusively psychological or neurological analysis. This methodological limitation – mainly linked to the focus on the “interiority” specific to emotion – does not allow us to truly address certain social or political issues related to emotions (such as, for example, the origins and manifestations of fear induced by a pandemic within a population). This is particularly the case with the question of the effects of “collective emotions” which requires conceptualization work that philosophy is able to produce (see in particular the excellent presentation made by Salmela [2020]). Following Livet [2002] but also Rimé [2005], it is a question of questioning the way in which an emotion can be "shared" socially, imitated, "aggregated", felt collectively or transmitted, etc., within a community, a population or even a group. The above leads us to question the scope of emotion within the institutional economy. As we have suggested, the eco-Emmanuel Petit— ... Paradoxically, this potential has not yet been realized, neither with regard to the “old” institutionalism of John Commons or Thorstein Veblen, nor with regard to neo-institutionalism (Patalano [2010]), emotion remaining to this day in our opinion the missing piece of this current of analysis. Some recent conceptual work, however, suggests that it is possible to “endogenize” individual emotions in such a way as to account for their active role in modifying the subject’s environment. Petit and Ballet [2021], for example, translate this idea of ​​endogeneity using John Dewey’s theory of emotions. For the pragmatist author, emotion signals the need for change and is at the same time an active and central agent in the reconfiguration of individual habits. We can then consider a modification of habits, through emotion, which goes well beyond what the behavioral theory of “nudge” can propose (Thaler and Sunstein [2010]).

Recently, the "France Tele-com case9" is an interesting illustration of how the dynamics of emotion can lead to a favorable change - via the recognition of "institutional moral harassment" - in the rules that structure the law and life at work.

Beyond this illustration, taking into account emotions (individual or collective) that are endogenous to the course of our lives within institutional frameworks is intended to allow us to better understand societal issues – epidemics, climate change, migration, inequalities, etc. – within which emotions represent a major phenomenon. 5. In conclusion When, more than thirty years ago, economists began to mobilize the register of emotion in their work, they most often did so in a rather vague way – not making a distinction (as psychologists do today) between mood, emotion and feeling. Furthermore, their analysis was based on scattered, rather undeveloped and imprecise elements of the theory of emotions. Since Elster's seminal review [1998], the introduction of emotion into analysis has received greater attention and has been the subject of a rapidly expanding literature. 9.

The "France Telecom" affair is linked to stress management methods that have become increasingly widespread in certain countries, particularly in France, during the 2000s. They have been the cause of waves of suicides in the workplace in companies using these methods, particularly within France Telecom, where 23 suicides in the workplace were recorded between 2008 and 2009.
Fueled by legitimate indignation, a trial took place in December 2019, sanctioning the CEO at the time.

The most important legal consequence of this trial, however, was the recognition of the concept of “institutional moral harassment” which calls into question the human resources management policy and announces a necessary change in these management rules.206—————————— Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review REP 132 (2) March-April 2022The convergence which is evident today in the multidisciplinary scientific approach to emotion – via a fertile overlap of analyses and a reduction or relaxation of oppositions (between, for example, the psychological and biological approach and history, anthropology or philosophy) – does not, however, seem to characterize the economic approach.
Overall, the contributions of experimental economics, sociology or the institutionalist approach still remain very compartmentalized.

Given the very nature of emotion – linked to the body, to cognition as much as to the social – it seems to us that these literatures would deserve to be further identified, analyzed and especially “mixed” or “nested”. By contributing to linking the construction of the theory of emotions and its transposition into economic analysis, we hope however to have contributed, in this review article, to strengthening these links.
